choices.text: 1 E, 2 D, 3 C, 4 B, 5 A
1 A, 2 C, 3 B, 4 D, 5 E
1 E, 2 C, 3 D, 4 B, 5 A
1 B, 2 C, 3 D, 4 E, 5 A

questions.text:
Match the correct number with the parts of the cuff system of an endotracheal tube

A. Inflation valve
B. Pilot balloon
C. Inflation lumen
D. Inflation tube
E. Cuff Length
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A cuff system consists of the cuff plus an inflation system, which includes an inflation tube, a pilot balloon, and an inflation valve.
  • An inflation lumen in the tube wall may also be present.
  • The purpose of the cuff system is to provide a seal between the tube and tracheal wall to prevent passage of pharyngeal contents into the trachea and ensure that no gas leaks past the cuff during positive pressure ventilation.
  • The cuff also serves to centre the tube in the trachea.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false.
Assertion is true but reason is false.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is correct for assertion.
Assertion is false, reason is true.

questions.text:
Identify the correct option regarding the following picture

Assertion: The Given instrument is used to insert or remove pharyngeal pack and to remove foreign bodies from the upper airway or oesophagus
Reason: The instrument is designed such that when the larynx is exposed, most of the forceps are out of the line of sight.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The instrument depicted is Magill's forceps, specifically shaped to guide devices into the larynx or oesophagus without obstructing the operator's view.
  • Key Features of Magill's forceps:
    • Angled jaws: align with the airway axis for precise grasping of tubes, packs, or objects.
    • Long, slender shaft: allows deep insertion without obstructing the line of sight.
    • Blunt, atraumatic tips: minimize mucosal injury during manipulation.
  • Indications / Applications:
    • Insertion and removal of pharyngeal packs during ENT or oral surgery
    • Extraction of foreign bodies from the oropharynx or upper oesophagus
    • Guiding nasotracheal or orogastric tubes into the larynx or oesophageal inlet
    • Adjusting endotracheal tube position under laryngoscopic view

choices.text: Enables the operator to 'look around the corner'
More useful in guiding the trainees in laryngoscopy
Movement of the cervical spine is less
Endotracheal intubation is easier even without the use of a pre-shaped stylet

questions.text: Advantages of the given instrument over conventional laryngoscopy are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement, Endotracheal intubation is easier even without the use of a pre-shaped stylet is not true since video laryngoscopes may require a pre-shaped stylet to facilitate intubation in certain cases like

  • Severely anterior larynx where tube trajectory must match blade curvature
  • Restricted mouth opening (<2.5 cm) limiting blade manipulation
  • Patients with prior airway surgery or distorted pharyngeal anatomy

Laryngeal anatomy as seen during laryngoscopy

Advantages of video laryngoscopy over conventional laryngoscopy include:

  • Enables the operator to 'look around the corner':
    • Video laryngoscopy provides a clear view of the glottis and vocal cords, which can sometimes be challenging with a conventional direct laryngoscopy. It allows the operator to see the airway structures more easily.
  • More useful in guiding the trainees in laryngoscopy:
    • Video laryngoscopy provides a visual display that can be beneficial for teaching
  • Movement of the cervical spine is less.
    • Video laryngoscopy often allows for a more neutral position of the patient's cervical spine during intubation. This can be advantageous, especially in patients with potential cervical spine injuries.
  • Reduced applied force:
    • Less lifting force lowers risk of dental trauma and oropharyngeal injury.
  • Adjustable blade options
    • Multiple blade shapes/sizes cater to pediatric and adult anatomies.

choices.text: Less chances of laryngospasm and bronchospasm
Allows higher peak airway pressures intraoperatively

questions.text: In a 45-year-old female weighing 98 kg, posted for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, factors that are in favour of intubation with a cuffed endotracheal tube rather than a supraglottic airway device are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Because of no laryngeal manipulation or trauma by a supraglottic airway, it causes fewer incidences of laryngospasm and bronchospasm as compared to an endotracheal tube.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 16 kg is scheduled for inguinal hernia repair. She is at the 55th percentile for height for her age. An appropriately sized uncuffed endotracheal tube for this patient will have an internal diameter of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For Paediatric sizing (< 4 years): Use (Age ÷ 4) + 4.5 = (4 ÷ 4) + 4.5 = 5.5 mm.
  • Paediatric tubes come in 0.5 mm increments so choose 0 mm to allow a slight air leak at 20-30 cm H2O and protect the airway mucosa.
  • Serious life-long laryngeal and subglottic damage can result from using inappropriately large ETTs, particularly in children with inflammatory lesions of the upper airway such as laryngotracheobronchitis.
  • ETT sizing depends on age. Internal diameters range from 5 - 10.5 mm.
  • Adult guidelines:
    • Male: 8.0 - 9.0 mm ID
    • Female: 7.0 - 8.0 mm ID
  • Paediatric formulas:
    • < 4 years: (Age ÷ 4) + 4.5
    • > 4 years: (Age ÷ 3) + 3.5
  • Uncuffed tubes are preferred in children < 8 years to match the funnel-shaped airway and avoid subglottic injury.
  • Confirm correct fit by detecting a slight leak at 20 - 30 cm H2O.

questions.text: the contents with the correct drawer in the difficult airway cart.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Each drawer is labelled to indicate contents as per the plans.
  • Drawer 1 (plan A):Tracheal intubation
    • Laryngoscopy handles, blades, different-sized endotracheal tubes, Magill forceps, etc
  • Drawer 2 (plan B): Oxygenation  through SAD (supraglottic airway device)
    • Different-sized 2nd-gen SADs, fibre optic adjuncts
  • Drawer 3 (plan C):Face mask ventilation
    • Facemasks, nasopharyngeal airways, oropharyngeal airways
  • Drawer 4 (plan D):Surgical cricothyroidotomy kit
  • Drawer 5 (plan E):Cannula cricothyroidotomy kit

Reference: https://das.uk.com/files/Difficult_airway_trolley_DAS.pdf

choices.text: Put a smaller size LMA and ventilate
Intubate with appropriate sized endotracheal tube and ventilate
Abort the procedure and wake up the patient

questions.text: A 42-year-old, 120 kg patient is posted for a laparoscopic umbilical hernia repair. After insertion of a supraglottic device, it is observed that the peak airway pressure required to ventilate the patient is about 40 cmH2O. What will be the next best step in airway management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Obese and laparoscopic patients often require higher ventilation pressures due to reduced compliance
  • Supraglottic airways seal only to ~28 cm H2O; pressures above this → gastric insufflation and aspiration risk.
  • Peak pressure 40 cm H2O exceeds LMA seal → switch to cuffed ETT for a reliable tracheal seal.
  • Endotracheal intubation provides a cuffed seal, allowing safe ventilation at higher pressures without aspiration risk.

Explanation of other options:

  • Continuing (Option A) risks aspiration from gastric insufflation.
  • A smaller LMA (Option B) further reduces seal pressure, worsening leak and aspiration risk.
  • Aborting the procedure (Option D) is unnecessary if a secure airway can be achieved with intubation.

choices.text: Replace the ETT with a smaller-sized uncuffed tube
Replace the ETT with a larger-sized uncuffed tube
Replace the ETT with a 4.0-mm cuffed ETT

questions.text: A healthy 2-year-old male is scheduled to undergo a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. His airway was managed uneventfully with mask ventilation, which was followed by direct laryngoscopy and intubation with a 5.0mm uncuffed endotracheal tube (ETT). Manual ventilation produces an air leak in the oropharynx beginning at a peak pressure of 20 cm H2O. The best next step in the anaesthetic management is to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Correct tube size and appropriate cuff inflation are confirmed by easy passage into the larynx and the development of a gas leak at 15 to 25 cm H2O pressure (which is acceptable as described in the case as leak above 20 cm of H20)
  • No leak (>25 cm H2O) indicates an oversized tube or overinflated cuff that should be replaced or deflated to prevent postoperative oedema, whereas an excessive leak (<15 cm H2O) may preclude adequate ventilation and contaminate the operating room with anaesthetic gases.

Explanation of other options:

  • A smaller tube (Option B) would cause an excessive leak (<15 cm H2O), risking and hypoventilation and contamination of the operating room
    contamination of the operating room.
  • A larger tube (Option C) would eliminate the leak (>25 cm H2O), increasing the risk of airway trauma.
  • Switching to a cuffed ETT (Option D )is unnecessary when an uncuffed tube is appropriately sized and the leak is optimal.

choices.text: Presence of spirals embedded in the tube
High incidence of kinking with these tubes
Elastic recoil leading to accidental extubation

questions.text: A 40-year-old female is posted for thyroidectomy for multinodular goitre, for which her airway is secured using the following airway device. Immediately following intubation, it was found impossible to ventilate the patient. Which characteristic of the given device can be responsible for this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is that of a spiral-embedded/armoured/flex metallic endotracheal tube.

  • The purpose of the Murphy's eye is to provide an alternate pathway for gas flow if the bevel becomes occluded in an endotracheal tube.
  • Spiral embedded tubes don't have Murphy's eye in them due to the presence of the metallic spirals.
  • Without a Murphy's eye, the bevel can abut the mucosa and completely block gas flow, causing immediate inability to ventilate.
  • Spirals (Option B) are a design feature to resist kinking, not to cause obstruction.
  • Armoured tubes (Option C) have a lower kinking incidence due to embedded wire.
  • Elastic recoil may contribute to migration over time, but would not cause complete immediate airway obstruction. (Option D)

questions.text: During awake fiberoptic intubation in a patient with limited mouth opening, which nerve block is most appropriate to anesthetize the posterior third of the tongue and suppress the gag reflex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX) provides both general sensation and taste to the posterior one-third of the tongue and adjacent oropharynx, so its block abolishes gag reflex and discomfort during scope passage.
  • Superior laryngeal block (Option A) prevents cough but does not affect posterior tongue sensation.
  • Lingual nerve block (Option C) numbs anterior tongue only-insufficient for gag suppression.
  • Hypoglossal block (Option D) provides motor paralysis, not sensory anesthesia.

choices.text: The base of the anterior tonsillar pillar
Medial to the lesser cornu of the hyoid bone
Superior to the superior cornu of the thyroid cartilage

questions.text: To anaesthetise the supraglottic laryngeal mucosa, the local anaesthetic should be injected into which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sensory innervation of the larynx above the vocal cords is carried by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • The SLN descends between the greater cornu of the hyoid bone and the superior cornu of the thyroid cartilage.
  • Injecting local anaesthetic superior to the superior cornu of the thyroid cartilage blocks the internal SLN, anaesthetising the supraglottic mucosa.

Explanation of other options:

  • Base of the anterior tonsillar pillar (Option A): This is the site for a glossopharyngeal nerve block. Injection here anaesthetises the posterior tongue, vallecula, and oropharynx but does not reach the internal SLN supplying the supraglottic larynx.
  • Medial to the lesser cornu of the hyoid bone (Option B): No major sensory branch runs here. The internal SLN lies between the greater cornu of the hyoid and the superior cornu of the thyroid cartilage; an injection medial to the lesser cornu will miss the nerve entirely.
  • Through the cricothyroid membrane (Option B): This transtracheal block delivers local anaesthetic to the recurrent laryngeal nerve territory, anaesthetising the infraglottic mucosa and vocal cords. It does not anaesthetise the supraglottic region served by the internal SLN.

choices.text: A, B, and C are correct
A, B, C, and D are correct.

questions.text:
About the given equipment, choose the option

A. There is no need to discontinue ventilation or positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) while using it.
B. It is not necessary to hyperoxygenate the patient prior to usage
C. Lower rates of nosocomial infections
D. Increased incidence of accidental extubation with its use.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is that of a closed suction catheter a sterile catheter enclosed within the ventilator circuit.

Uses:

  • Allows removal of airway secretions in intubated, mechanically ventilated patients without disconnecting the ventilator.

Advantages:

  • Preserves ventilation and PEEP throughout suctioning (Option A).
  • Maintains FiO2, making pre-oxygenation often unnecessary (Option B).
  • Enclosed system minimizes catheter contamination and reduces nosocomial infection rates compared to open suction (Option C).

Disadvantages:

  • Added weight on the endotracheal tube may pull on the airway, increasing risk of trauma or accidental extubation unless properly supported (Option D).

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false.
Assertion is true but reason is false.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is correct for assertion.
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not correct for assertion

questions.text:
For the following instrument, choose the correct option

Assertion: The margin of safety for right-sided tubes is considerably less than for left-sided tubes.
Reason: The right upper lobe bronchus is very close to the origin of the right mainstem bronchus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The illustration shows a standard cuffed endotracheal tube placed into the right mainstem bronchus.

Assertion (True):

  • "Margin of safety" is defined as the length of bronchus distal to the tube tip before obstructing a lobar opening.
  • Right mainstem margin ≈ 1-2 cm; left mainstem margin ≈ 4-5 cm.

Reason (True & Explanatory):

  • The right upper lobe bronchus originates only ~1-2 cm from the carina, whereas the left upper lobe branches farther downstream.
  • Thus, slight over-advancement on the right side easily blocks the upper lobe.

Anatomical Considerations:

  • The right main bronchus descends almost in line with the trachea at an angle of about 25°, making it relatively vertical.
  • The left main bronchus diverges more laterally at approximately 45°, resulting in a steeper, more oblique course.

Clinical Implications:

  • Always confirm tube depth by auscultating both lung fields and checking insertion markers.
  • Use fiber-optic visualization or chest imaging when precise placement is critical.

choices.text: Proper lubrication of endotracheal tube before insertion

questions.text: How can one avoid the catastrophic complication shown in the given image of a patient with a misplaced endotracheal tube in a basilar skull fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is that of a radiograph demonstrating an endotracheal tube placed through the cribriform plate into the cranial vault in a patient with a basilar skull fracture.
  • In basilar skull fractures, the cribriform plate is disrupted, creating a path into the cranial vault.
  • Nasal passage of ETTs, airways, or nasogastric catheters carries a greater risk in patients with severe midfacial trauma because of the risk of intracranial placement and hence is contraindicated.
  • Oral intubation via direct or video laryngoscopy avoids this route and prevents such injury.
  • Basilar skull fractures often present with "raccoon eyes," CSF rhinorrhea, or Battle's sign, any of which contraindicate nasal instrumentation.
  • Always assess facial trauma and imaging before choosing nasal routes for airway or gastric access.
  • No other given options can protect from intracranial placement of the airway device.

choices.text: Ankylosing spondylitis with limited neck mobility
Requirement for emergent cricothyrotomy in penetrating neck trauma
Neurological deficits after high-energy blunt trauma

questions.text: Which of the following following scenarios represents a contraindication to the procedure demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Explanaion:

  • Manual Inline Stabilization is used to maintain neutral cervical alignment whenever there is risk of spine instability, but must be released if it blocks access to an urgently needed front-of-neck airway (emergent cricothyrotomy)
  • One individual holds the head firmly with the patient on a backboard, the cervical collar left alone if in place, ensuring that neither the head nor neck moves with direct laryngoscopy.
  • A second person applies cricoid pressure, and the third performs laryngoscopy and intubation.
  • Trauma patients with unstable necks or whose necks have not yet been "cleared"/screened to rule out cervical injury are also candidates for MILS.
  • As limited mouth opening affects oro-tracheal intubation, a commonly used practice is removing the anterior half of a semi-rigid collar and having an assistant provide manual in-line stabilisation during intubation.

Indications for MILS:

  • Suspected or confirmed cervical spine fracture (Option A)
  • High-energy blunt trauma with neurological signs (paresthesia, paralysis) (Option D)
  • Inflammatory spinal disorders (ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis) (Option B)
  • Unstable cervical spine post-surgery or tumour
  • Transport and positioning when cervical collar removal is needed for airway access

Contraindications to MILS:

  • Need for immediate surgical airway (cricothyrotomy/tracheostomy) that MILS would obstruct
  • Penetrating neck injuries requiring rapid airway control at the site
  • Situations where inline hold prevents hemorrhage control at airway wound
  • Extreme facial/oral trauma where MILS impedes access to airway or bleeding control

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a primary risk factor for difficult mask ventilation ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A high-arched palate affects oral anatomy, not mask seal, and therefore is a marker for difficult intubation rather than mask ventilation.

Additional predictors of difficult tracheal intubation:

  • Mallampati class III or IV
  • Mouth opening < 3 cm
  • Thyromental distance < 6 cm
  • Limited neck extension or cervical spine immobility
  • Micrognathia or retrognathia
  • Macroglossia or large tongue
  • Presence of upper airway masses or tumors

Mask ventilation can be made difficult by anything that prevents the face mask from forming an adequate seal with the patient's face (e.g., a beard) or increases the resistance to airflow between the mouth and larynx.

Key Takeaway:

Difficult mask ventilation can be remembered by BONES

  • Beard
  • Obesity
  • No teeth
  • Elderly
  • Snorer

questions.text: Refer to the given x-ray of a pediatric patient post-intubation. Which of the following steps would most reliably prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a chest x-ray of inadvertent Endobronchial intubationleading to atelectasis in a pediatric patient. Because fiber-optic bronchoscopy confirms tube tip position at or just above the carina under direct vision, it most reliably prevents endobronchial intubation.
  • Direct visualization is faster and more accurate than clinical signs or chest x-ray, especially in small airways of children.
  • Auscultation may be misleading, as breath sounds can be transmitted to the opposite side of the chest in the presence of bronchial intubation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Pulse oximetry often remains normal when high FiO2 is delivered, delaying detection. (Option B ruled out)
  • Monitoring expired CO2 may lead to the discovery of bronchial intubation, but it is not a reliable means to detect this problem. Either an increase or decrease in end-tidal CO2 may be seen. (Option C ruled out)

Additional complications of endobronchial intubation:

  • In children: atelectasis of the non-ventilated lung, hypoxemia, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, risk of unilateral overdistension leading to barotrauma
  • In adults: contralateral lung collapse or consolidation, volutrauma/barotrauma in the intubated lung, pulmonary edema, increased intrathoracic pressure impairing venous return
  • Delayed recognition may lead to pneumonia, prolonged mechanical ventilation, or hemodynamic instability

Other prevention strategies of endobronchial intubation:

  • Use age - or size - based depth formulas
  • Confirm bilateral chest rise and symmetrical breath sounds immediately after intubation.
  • Employ bedside ultrasound to visualize pleural sliding bilaterally
  • Verify position with capnography waveform shape and consistency of CO2 levels in both lungs (though less specific).

questions.text: What does the "Double tract sign" in airway ultrasound indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The double-tract sign appears when two parallel hyperechoic lines with associated reverberation artefacts are seen - one from the tracheal air-mucosa interface and a second from an air-filled oesophagus containing the misplaced tube.

  • The image shows a transverse view of the trachea and oesophagus during an oesophagal intubation.
  • Esophagus is visualized posterior and lateral to the trachea. Two parallel echogenic lines are seen in the proximal oesophagus, representing the inner and outer walls of the endotracheal (ET) tube as it passes through the lumen of the oesophagus.

Explanation of other options:

  • Tracheal intubation (Option A) shows a single air - mucosa interface without a second tract.
  • Pneumothorax (Option B) diagnosed by absent lung sliding and presence of "barcode" or "stratosphere" sign on M - mode.
  • Hemothorax (Option D) detected by pleural effusion appearance, not by airway ultrasound.

questions.text: Conditions where cricothyrotomy may be indicated include all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laryngeal inflammation (e.g., epiglottitis) involves edematous, friable tissue around the cricothyroid membrane, increasing bleeding risk and making the membrane difficult to identify

Cricothyrotomy should not be used in the presence of laryngeal inflammation or infection.

Types of Cricothyroidotomy:

  • Needle cricothyroidotomy: wide - bore cannula (14 G or 16 G) for temporary oxygenation.
  • Surgical (tube) cricothyroidotomy: scalpel - bougie - tube technique for definitive airway.

Indications:

  • "Cannot intubate, cannot ventilate" emergencies
  • Cervical spine injury preventing neck manipulation (Option A)
  • Surgery or obstruction of the upper airway (Option B)
  • Difficult intubation scenarios where other supraglottic devices fail (Option C)

Contraindications:

  • Laryngeal inflammation or infection
  • Children < 12 years (risk of subglottic injury)
  • Severe coagulopathy
  • Distorted neck anatomy from tumor or prior surgery

choices.text: Seals to a relatively low airway pressure
Position is less stable in edentulous patients.
Is not a part of the difficult airway algorithm

questions.text: All of the following are disadvantages of the device given in the figure except.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Laryngeal Mask Airway Classic is a part of the difficult airway algorithm.

Aperture bars may prevent the epiglottis from blocking the airway.

LMA generations and types

  • First-generation: Classic, Flexible, Fastrach
  • Second-generation: ProSeal (drain tube), Supreme (integrated bite block + drain), i-gel (non-inflatable cuff)

choices.text: Can be used in positive pressure ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of a fenestrated tracheostomy tube over a non-fenestrated tube?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fenestrations in a tracheostomy tube are used to allow exhalation through the glottis as part of the weaning process, and in particular to permit speech.
  • Speech and airway patency are restored when the inner cannula is removed, permitting phonation via the fenestration and upper airway.
  • Fenestrated tubes help assess airway competence before full tube removal, providing a stepwise approach to decannulation.

Indications for use:

  • Assessment of upper-airway patency during weaning
  • Facilitation of speech in tracheostomized patients
  • Gradual decannulation from mechanical ventilation
  • Enhancement of cough efficacy and secretion clearance

questions.text: A nasopharyngeal airway may be used as an airway adjunct in all of the following conditions except patients with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Active nasal bleeding risks further mucosal injury and airway obstruction, so epistaxis contraindicates nasopharyngeal airway
  • The nasopharyngeal airway is a simple airway adjunct that can be used to facilitate ventilation and removal of secretions. They bypass oral obstructions to facilitate ventilation and secretion clearance via the nasal route.
  • It is a soft-silicone, curved tube with flange and beveled end, inserted via the nostril to sit above the epiglottis.
  • Always inspect nasal passages for deformity or obstruction before insertion.
  • Lubricate generously and choose correct size (nose tip to earlobe).

Explanation of other options:

  • Intact gag reflex (Option A) is not a contraindication, NPAs stimulate less gag than oropharyngeal airways.
  • Trismus (Option B) prevents oral airway placement but permits nasal insertion.
  • Oral trauma (Option D) may preclude oropharyngeal devices, making NPA preferable.

choices.text: Emergency rescue airway after failed intubation
Primary airway for routine elective anaesthesia
Short-term ventilatory support in ICU weaning trials

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary use of this device?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is of an esophageal-tracheal combitube (ETC). It provides a rapid blind-insertion rescue airway when endotracheal intubation fails, enabling ventilation via dual lumina regardless of placement
  • The ETC is inserted blindly either into the trachea or esophagus.
  • Both proximal and distal lumens can ventilate the patient:
    • Oesophageal placement: ventilation via distal lumen perforations above the cuff into the hypopharynx
    • Tracheal placement: ventilation directly through the proximal lumen
  • Use of the ETC as a primary airway is limited by a higher risk of complications, compared with the LMA or tracheal intubation, including hoarseness, dysphagia, and bleeding. (Option B ruled out)
  • Contraindications: caustic ingestion, known oesophageal pathology, latex allergy
  • Unsuitable for ICU weaning trials as it lacks cuff-pressure monitoring and is not designed for prolonged ventilation. (Option C ruled out)
  • While it does allow gastric decompression, its primary role remains emergency airway rescue, not routine stomach drainage. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Clinical conditions that may require independent lung ventilation include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Respiratory distress syndrome involves diffuse bilateral pathology; lung isolation won't improve gas exchange or protect the contralateral lung.
  • Independent lung ventilation (via double-lumen tube) isolates one lung to:
    • Prevent contamination (blood, pus) from an infected or fistulous lung
    • Facilitate surgical exposure during lobectomy or other thoracic procedures
  • Double-lumen endobronchial tubes have two lumens and cuffs, allowing selective ventilation and deflation of either lung.
